intro: Jacobinia penrhosiensis, commonly known as the Penrhos Island hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the island of Penrhos in the Cook Islands. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton plants. The plant is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to red, typically blooming during the warmer months. Its leaves are ovate and covered in a fine, soft pubescence, contributing to its ornamental appeal. Jacobinia penrhosiensis is often found growing in coastal areas and is adapted to the tropical climate of its native habitat.
